title: In “The book has been lying there for weeks,” why is ‘lying’ used instead of ‘laying?’ - Quora

response.answer_text: “laying” means “the act of putting down something carefully”. It’s the present continuous form of the verb “lay”. It’s a transitive verb, which means it needs a grammatical object (lay the baby, lay an egg, etc). “lying” can mean two things and is the present continuous form of “lie”. It can mean “not telling the truth” or, in this sentence, the book has been lying there for weeks, “staying in a fixed position”.  Tell me if I missed something or made a mistake.

"Lying" is intransitive. It takes no object. "Laying" is transitive. It needs an object. Transitive: the chicken has been laying eggs for weeks. Subject: chicken Verb: has been laying Object: eggs The book isn't laying anything, eggs or otherwise. It is just lying there.
